data.name: Number the rationals
data.description:
Number the rationals


The Kata is based on this one : [List of all rationals](https://www.codewars.com/kata/5e4e8f5a72d9550032953717) But now, we are dealing with some really large values ...

Abstract :

It can be shown that every positive rational number appears only once in the infinite binary tree : ``` 1/1 / \ 1/2 2/1 / \ / \ 1/3 3/2 2/3 3/1 / \ / \ / \ / \ 1/4 4/3 3/5 5/2 2/5 5/3 3/4 4/1 / \ .... ``` For each node of type ```a/b``` with ```a>0``` and ```b>0``` 1) The value of the left node below ```a/b``` is ```a/(a+b)``` 2) The value of the right node below ```a/b``` is ```(a+b)/b``` For example, the node ```3/2``` has two leaves ```3/(2+3) = 3/5``` and ```(3+2)/2 = 5/2``` Reading the values line by line, we get the rationals list : ```[1/1, 1/2, 2/1, 1/3, 3/2, 2/3, 3/1, 1/4, 4/3, 3/5, 5/2, ... ]```

Task :

1) Define a function ```to_int``` that takes two positive integers ```a``` and ```b``` representing a positive rational ```a/b``` and returns the corresponding position in the list (1 based index) For example : * ```to_int(1, 1) = to_int(5, 5) = 1``` * ```to_int(1, 3) = 4``` * ```to_int(4, 1) = to_int(8, 2) = 15``` 2) You must also define a function ```to_frac``` that takes a positive integer ```n``` and returns a tuple ```(a, b)``` corresponding to the rational in the list (1 based index) and where ```a``` and ```b``` are relatively prime For example : * ```to_frac(1) = (1, 1)``` * ```to_frac(4) = (1, 3)``` * ```to_frac(15) = (4, 1)``` You will aways get valid input.(@Chrono79) Good Luck!
